div.p: FNCV 022-030, Archives, Field Naturalists Club of Victoria, Melbourne.
President of the Victorian Field-Naturalists Club.

It is to me a great satisfaction, dear President, that I am at last enabled, to place before the Club, (though yet in loose sheets only) the complete dichotomy of the Vict. orders, genera and species of native plants, supported in each case by diagnostic notes, so that the volume will form indeed an abridged "Flora".
B88.13.03.

I can fairly assert, that I carried out this severe task with conscientiousness and regardless of the sacrifice of so much time, which at my stage of life becomes more and more allotted to the finishing work of my career. Now a list of vernaculars, some tables to facilitate finding out the names of plants, a simple enumeration of the immigrated plants, the preface and the index need yet to be printed, but the msc.
manuscript. is also for all this nearly completed. Thus some bound copies of the whole work, comprising about 550 pages, will be surely ready for next months meeting of the Club.

To judge this volume justly, the essay should be read, which through my accident could not be finished in time for the Sydney meeting of the Australian Association for the advancement of science; but that treatise was placed on the 3. of this month before the RS. of N.SW.,
B89.13.05. so that impressions of it can be submitted along with the ready volume to the next monthly meeting of the Club. My views on the dichotomous system and the manner in which I applied, as well as my reasons for effecting some changes in the organography are discussed fully in that essay.

— And now, my dear President, if after all the mental toil, bestowed on that volume, any one, who may use it, will show some little gratitude, it could best be done by openly and encouragingly acknowledging any advantages, which may be derived from the work in the field or in the study. To so much thanks, I trust, I am entitled. I expect nothing more.
